para.sentence: (For other notation see LABEL:about.notations.)
real variable.
complex variable.
real or complex parameters.
nonnegative integers.
arbitrary small positive constant.
gamma function (§LABEL:sec:GA.Def.GP).
\Gamma'\left(z\right)/\Gamma\left(z\right).
Unless otherwise indicated, primes denote derivatives with respect to the argument.

The functions treated in this chapter are the incomplete gamma functions \gamma\left(a,z\right) , \Gamma\left(a,z\right) , \gamma^{*}\left(a,z\right) , P\left(a,z\right) , and Q\left(a,z\right) ; the incomplete beta functions \mathrm{B}_{x}\left(a,b\right) and I_{x}\left(a,b\right) ; the generalized exponential integral E_{p}\left(z\right) ; the generalized sine and cosine integrals \mathrm{si}\left(a,z\right) , \mathrm{ci}\left(a,z\right) , \mathrm{Si}\left(a,z\right) , and \mathrm{Ci}\left(a,z\right).

Alternative notations include:Prym’s functions P_{z}(a)=\gamma\left(a,z\right) , Q_{z}(a)=\Gamma\left(a,z\right) , ( , pp. 25–26) , ( , p. 63) ; (a,z)!=\gamma\left(a+1,z\right ), [a,z]!=\Gamma\left(a+1,z\right ), ( ) ; B(a,b,x)=\mathrm{B}_{x}\left(a,b\right) , I(a,b,x)=I_{x}\left(a,b\right) , ( ) ; \mathrm{Si}\left(a,x\right)\to\mathrm{Si}\left(1-a,x\right) , \mathrm{Ci}\left(a,x\right)\to\mathrm{Ci}\left(1-a,x\right) , ( ) .

The general values of the incomplete gamma functions \gamma\left(a,z\right) and \Gamma\left(a,z\right) are defined by \gamma\left(a,z\right)=\int_{0}^{z}t^{a-1}e^{-t}\mathrm{d}t, subject to \Re a>0, , \Gamma\left(a,z\right)=\int_{z}^{\infty}t^{a-1}e^{-t}\mathrm{d}t, without restrictions on the integration paths.

However, when the integration paths do not cross the negative real axis, and in the case of (LABEL:eq:IG.DEF.2) exclude the origin, \gamma\left(a,z\right) and \Gamma\left(a,z\right) take their principal values; compare §LABEL:sec:EF.FN.LOG.
Except where indicated otherwise in the DLMF these principal values are assumed. For example, \gamma\left(a,z\right)+\Gamma\left(a,z\right)=\Gamma\left(a\right), subject to a\neq 0,-1,-2,\dots.

Normalized functions are: P\left(a,z\right)=\frac{\gamma\left(a,z\right)}{\Gamma\left(a\right)}, Q\left(a,z\right)=\frac{\Gamma\left(a,z\right)}{\Gamma\left(a\right)}, P\left(a,z\right)+Q\left(a,z\right)=1.
In addition, \gamma^{*}\left(a,z\right)=z^{-a}P\left(a,z\right)=\frac{z^{-a}}{\Gamma\left(a \right)}\gamma\left(a,z\right).
\gamma^{*}\left(a,z\right)=\frac{1}{\Gamma\left(a\right)}\int_{0}^{1}t^{a-1}e^ {-zt}\mathrm{d}t, subject to \Re a>0.
In this subsection the functions \gamma and \Gamma have their general values.
The function \gamma^{*}\left(a,z\right) is entire in z and a.
When z\neq 0 , \Gamma\left(a,z\right) is an entire function of a , and \gamma\left(a,z\right) is meromorphic with simple poles at a=-n , n=0,1,2,\dots , with residue (-1)^{n}/n!

For m\in\mathbb{Z} , \gamma\left(a,ze^{2\pi mi}\right)=e^{2\pi mia}\gamma\left(a,z\right), subject to a\neq 0,-1,-2,\dots, , \Gamma\left(a,ze^{2\pi mi}\right)=e^{2\pi mia}\Gamma\left(a,z\right)+(1-e^{2 \pi mia})\Gamma\left(a\right).
(LABEL:eq:IG.DEF.10) also holds when a is zero or a negative integer, provided that the right-hand side is replaced by its limiting value.
For example, in the case m=-1 we have e^{-\pi ia}\Gamma\left(a,ze^{\pi i}\right)-e^{\pi ia}\Gamma\left(a,ze^{-\pi i} \right)=-\frac{2\pi i}{\Gamma\left(1-a\right)}, without restriction on a.
Lastly, \Gamma\left(a,ze^{\pm\pi i}\right)=\Gamma\left(a\right)(1-z^{a}e^{\pm\pi ia} \gamma^{*}\left(a,-z\right)).
If w=\gamma\left(a,z\right) or \Gamma\left(a,z\right) , then \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}w}{{\mathrm{d}z}^{2}}+\left(1+\frac{1-a}{z}\right)\frac{ \mathrm{d}w}{\mathrm{d}z}=0.
If w=e^{z}z^{1-a}\Gamma\left(a,z\right) , then \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}w}{{\mathrm{d}z}^{2}}-\left(1+\frac{1-a}{z}\right)\frac{ \mathrm{d}w}{\mathrm{d}z}+\frac{1-a}{z^{2}}w=0.
Also, z\frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}\gamma^{*}}{{\mathrm{d}z}^{2}}+(a+1+z)\frac{\mathrm{d} \gamma^{*}}{\mathrm{d}z}+a\gamma^{*}=0.
Some monotonicity properties of \gamma^{*}\left(a,x\right) and \Gamma\left(a,x\right) in the four quadrants of the ( a,x )-plane in Figure LABEL:fig:IG.GV.RV.7 are given in ( , §9.6) .

subsection.title: Complex Argument

para.sentence: In the graphics shown in this subsection, height corresponds to the absolute value of the function and color to the phase.
See LABEL:doc.help.vrml.aboutcolor.

subsection.sentence: Figure 8.3.8: \Gamma\left(0.25,x+iy\right) , -3\leq x\leq 3 , -3\leq y\leq 3 . Principal value. There is a cut along the negative real axis. When x=y=0 , \Gamma\left(0.25,0\right)=\Gamma\left(0.25\right)=3.625\ldots .
Figure 8.3.9: \gamma\left(0.25,x+iy\right) , -3\leq x\leq 3 , -3\leq y\leq 3 . Principal value. There is a cut along the negative real axis.

Figure 8.3.14: \Gamma\left(2.5,x+iy\right) , -2.2\leq x\leq 3 , -3\leq y\leq 3 . Principal value. There is a cut along the negative real axis. When x=y=0 , \Gamma\left(2.5,0\right)=\Gamma\left(2.5\right)=1.329\ldots .
Figure 8.3.15: \gamma\left(2.5,x+iy\right) , -2.2\leq x\leq 3 , -3\leq y\leq 3 . Principal value. There is a cut along the negative real axis.

para.sentence: For \operatorname{erf}\left(z\right) , \operatorname{erfc}\left(z\right) , and F\left(z\right) , see §§LABEL:sec:ER.DF.ER,LABEL:sec:ER.DF.DA.
For E_{n}\left(z\right) see §LABEL:sec:IG.GEI.DEF.

\gamma\left(\tfrac{1}{2},z^{2}\right)=2\int_{0}^{z}e^{-t^{2}}\mathrm{d}t=\sqrt {\pi}\operatorname{erf}\left(z\right), \gamma^{*}\left(a,0\right)=\frac{1}{\Gamma\left(a+1\right)}, , \gamma^{*}\left(\tfrac{1}{2},-z^{2}\right)=\frac{2e^{z^{2}}}{z\sqrt{\pi}}F \left(z\right).

\Gamma\left(0,z\right)=\int_{z}^{\infty}t^{-1}e^{-t}\mathrm{d}t=E_{1}\left(z \right), \Gamma\left(1,z\right)=e^{-z}, \Gamma\left(\tfrac{1}{2},z^{2}\right)=2\int_{z}^{\infty}e^{-t^{2}}\mathrm{d}t= \sqrt{\pi}\operatorname{erfc}\left(z\right).

For n=0,1,2,\dots , \gamma\left(n+1,z\right)=n!(1-e^{-z}e_{n}(z)) , \Gamma\left(n+1,z\right)=n!e^{-z}e_{n}(z) ,, P\left(n+1,z\right)=1-e^{-z}e_{n}(z), , Q\left(n+1,z\right)=e^{-z}e_{n}(z), where e_{n}(z)=\sum_{k=0}^{n}\frac{z^{k}}{k!}.

Also \gamma^{*}\left(-n,z\right)=z^{n}, \Gamma\left(1-n,z\right)=z^{1-n}E_{n}\left(z\right), Q\left(n+\tfrac{1}{2},z^{2}\right)=\operatorname{erfc}\left(z\right)+\frac{e^{ -z^{2}}}{\sqrt{\pi}}\sum_{k=1}^{n}\frac{z^{2k-1}}{{\left(\tfrac{1}{2}\right)_{ k}}}, \Gamma\left(-n,z\right)=\frac{(-1)^{n}}{n!}\left(E_{1}\left(z\right)-e^{-z} \sum_{k=0}^{n-1}\frac{(-1)^{k}k!}{z^{k+1}}\right)=\frac{(-1)^{n}}{n!}\left( \psi\left(n+1\right)-\ln z\right)-z^{-n}\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}k=0\\ k\neq n\end{subarray}}^{\infty}\frac{(-z)^{k}}{k!(k-n)}.
For the confluent hypergeometric functions M , {\mathbf{M}} , U , and the Whittaker functions M_{\kappa,\mu} and W_{\kappa,\mu} , see §§LABEL:sec:CH.MU.DE.KU and LABEL:sec:CH.KM.DE.WH.
\gamma\left(a,z\right)=a^{-1}z^{a}e^{-z}M\left(1,1+a,z\right)=a^{-1}z^{a}M \left(a,1+a,-z\right), subject to a\neq 0,-1,-2,\dots.
\gamma^{*}\left(a,z\right)=e^{-z}{\mathbf{M}}\left(1,1+a,z\right)={\mathbf{M}} \left(a,1+a,-z\right).
\Gamma\left(a,z\right)=e^{-z}U\left(1-a,1-a,z\right)=z^{a}e^{-z}U\left(1,1+a,z \right).
\gamma\left(a,z\right)=a^{-1}z^{\frac{1}{2}a-\frac{1}{2}}e^{-\frac{1}{2}z}M_{ \frac{1}{2}a-\frac{1}{2},\frac{1}{2}a}\left(z\right).
\Gamma\left(a,z\right)=e^{-\frac{1}{2}z}z^{\frac{1}{2}a-\frac{1}{2}}W_{\frac{1 }{2}a-\frac{1}{2},\frac{1}{2}a}\left(z\right).
For the Bessel function J_{\nu}\left(z\right) and modified Bessel function K_{\nu}\left(z\right) , see §§LABEL:sec:BS.DEF.SS and LABEL:sec:BS.MDEF.SS.

\gamma\left(a,z\right)=\frac{z^{a}}{\sin\left(\pi a\right)}\int_{0}^{\pi}e^{z \cos t}\cos\left(at+z\sin t\right)\mathrm{d}t, subject to a\notin\mathbb{Z}, , \gamma\left(a,z\right)=z^{\frac{1}{2}a}\int_{0}^{\infty}e^{-t}t^{\frac{1}{2}a- 1}J_{a}\left(2\sqrt{zt}\right)\mathrm{d}t, subject to \Re a>0.
, \gamma\left(a,z\right)=z^{a}\int_{0}^{\infty}\exp\left(-at-ze^{-t}\right) \mathrm{d}t, subject to \Re a>0.

\Gamma\left(a,z\right)=\frac{z^{a}e^{-z}}{\Gamma\left(1-a\right)}\int_{0}^{ \infty}\frac{t^{-a}e^{-t}}{z+t}\mathrm{d}t, subject to |\operatorname{ph}z|<\pi, \Re a<1, , \Gamma\left(a,z\right)=z^{a}e^{-z}\int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{e^{-zt}}{(1+t)^{1-a}} \mathrm{d}t, subject to \Re z>0, , \Gamma\left(a,z\right)=\frac{2z^{\frac{1}{2}a}e^{-z}}{\Gamma\left(1-a\right)} \int_{0}^{\infty}e^{-t}t^{-\frac{1}{2}a}K_{a}\left(2\sqrt{zt}\right)\mathrm{d}t, subject to \Re a<1, , \Gamma\left(a,z\right)=z^{a}\int_{0}^{\infty}\exp\left(at-ze^{t}\right)\mathrm {d}t, subject to \Re z>0.

\gamma\left(a,z\right)=\frac{-\mathrm{i}z^{a}}{2\sin\left(\pi a\right)}\int_{- 1}^{(0+)}t^{a-1}e^{zt}\mathrm{d}t, subject to z\neq 0, a\notin\mathbb{Z}; t^{a-1} takes its principal value where the path intersects the positive real axis, and is continuous elsewhere on the path.

\Gamma\left(-a,ze^{\pm\pi i}\right)=\frac{e^{z}e^{\mp\pi\mathrm{i}a}}{\Gamma \left(1+a\right)}\int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{t^{a}e^{-zt}}{t-1}\mathrm{d}t, subject to \Re z>0, \Re a>-1, where the integration path passes above or below the pole at t=1 , according as upper or lower signs are taken.
In (LABEL:eq:IG.IR.12)–(LABEL:eq:IG.IR.14),

c is a real constant and the path of integration is indented (if necessary) so that in the case of (LABEL:eq:IG.IR.12) it separates the poles of the gamma function from the pole at s=a , in the case of (LABEL:eq:IG.IR.13) it is to the right of all poles, and in the case of (LABEL:eq:IG.IR.14) it separates the poles of the gamma function from the poles at s=0,1,2,\ldots.

\gamma\left(a,z\right)=\frac{1}{2\pi i}\int_{c-i\infty}^{c+i\infty}\frac{ \Gamma\left(s\right)}{a-s}z^{a-s}\mathrm{d}s, subject to |\operatorname{ph}z|<\tfrac{1}{2}\pi, a\neq 0,-1,-2,\dots, \Gamma\left(a,z\right)=\frac{1}{2\pi i}\int_{c-i\infty}^{c+i\infty}\Gamma\left (s+a\right)\frac{z^{-s}}{s}\mathrm{d}s, subject to |\operatorname{ph}z|<\tfrac{1}{2}\pi, , \Gamma\left(a,z\right)=-\frac{z^{a-1}e^{-z}}{\Gamma\left(1-a\right)}\*\frac{1} {2\pi i}\int_{c-i\infty}^{c+i\infty}\Gamma\left(s+1-a\right)\frac{\pi z^{-s}}{ \sin\left(\pi s\right)}\mathrm{d}s, subject to |\operatorname{ph}z|<\tfrac{3}{2}\pi, a\neq 1,2,3,\dots.
For collections of integral representations of \gamma\left(a,z\right) and \Gamma\left(a,z\right) see ( , §9.3) , ( , pp. 68–69) , ( , pp. 309–312) , ( , §3.10) , and ( , pp. 282–283) .
For the functions e_{n}(z) , {\mathsf{i}^{(1)}_{n}}\left(z\right) , and L^{(\alpha)}_{n}\left(x\right) see (LABEL:eq:IG.SV.10), §§LABEL:sec:BS.DBP.SS,and LABEL:sec:OP.CP.OR, respectively.
\gamma^{*}\left(a,z\right)=e^{-z}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\frac{z^{k}}{\Gamma\left(a +k+1\right)}=\frac{1}{\Gamma\left(a\right)}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\frac{(-z)^{k}}{ k!(a+k)}.

\gamma\left(a,x+y\right)-\gamma\left(a,x\right)=\Gamma\left(a,x\right)-\Gamma \left(a,x+y\right)=e^{-x}x^{a-1}\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{{\left(1-a\right)_{n} }}{(-x)^{n}}(1-e^{-y}e_{n}(y)), subject to |y|<|x|.

\Gamma\left(a,z\right)=\Gamma\left(a\right)-\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\frac{(-1)^{k}z ^{a+k}}{k!(a+k)}=\Gamma\left(a\right)\left(1-z^{a}e^{-z}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \frac{z^{k}}{\Gamma\left(a+k+1\right)}\right), subject to a\neq 0,-1,-2,\dots.
\gamma\left(a,x\right)=\Gamma\left(a\right)x^{\frac{1}{2}a}e^{-x}\sum_{n=0}^{ \infty}e_{n}(-1)x^{\frac{1}{2}n}I_{n+a}\left(\textstyle 2x^{1/2}\right), subject to a\neq 0,-1,-2,\dots.
\gamma^{*}\left(a,z\right)=e^{-\frac{1}{2}z}\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{{\left(1- a\right)_{n}}}{\Gamma\left(n+a+1\right)}{\left(2n+1\right)}{\mathsf{i}^{(1)}_{ n}}\left(\tfrac{1}{2}z\right).
\Gamma\left(a,x\right)=x^{a}e^{-x}\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{L^{(a)}_{n}\left(x \right)}{n+1}, subject to x>0.
For an expansion for \gamma\left(a,ix\right) in series of Bessel functions J_{n}\left(x\right) that converges rapidly when a>0 and x ( \geq 0 ) is small or moderate in magnitude see ( ) .
\gamma\left(a+1,z\right)=a\gamma\left(a,z\right)-z^{a}e^{-z}, \Gamma\left(a+1,z\right)=a\Gamma\left(a,z\right)+z^{a}e^{-z}.
If w(a,z)=\gamma\left(a,z\right) or \Gamma\left(a,z\right) , then w(a+2,z)-(a+1+z)w(a+1,z)+azw(a,z)=0.
z\gamma^{*}\left(a+1,z\right)=\gamma^{*}\left(a,z\right)-\frac{e^{-z}}{\Gamma \left(a+1\right)}.
P\left(a+1,z\right)=P\left(a,z\right)-\frac{z^{a}e^{-z}}{\Gamma\left(a+1\right )}, Q\left(a+1,z\right)=Q\left(a,z\right)+\frac{z^{a}e^{-z}}{\Gamma\left(a+1\right )}.

For n=0,1,2,\dots , \gamma\left(a+n,z\right)={\left(a\right)_{n}}\gamma\left(a,z\right)-z^{a}e^{-z }\sum_{k=0}^{n-1}\frac{\Gamma\left(a+n\right)}{\Gamma\left(a+k+1\right)}z^{k}, \gamma\left(a,z\right)=\frac{\Gamma\left(a\right)}{\Gamma\left(a-n\right)} \gamma\left(a-n,z\right)-z^{a-1}e^{-z}\sum_{k=0}^{n-1}\frac{\Gamma\left(a \right)}{\Gamma\left(a-k\right)}z^{-k}, \Gamma\left(a+n,z\right)={\left(a\right)_{n}}\Gamma\left(a,z\right)+z^{a}e^{-z }\sum_{k=0}^{n-1}\frac{\Gamma\left(a+n\right)}{\Gamma\left(a+k+1\right)}z^{k}, \Gamma\left(a,z\right)=\frac{\Gamma\left(a\right)}{\Gamma\left(a-n\right)} \Gamma\left(a-n,z\right)+z^{a-1}e^{-z}\sum_{k=0}^{n-1}\frac{\Gamma\left(a \right)}{\Gamma\left(a-k\right)}z^{-k}, P\left(a+n,z\right)=P\left(a,z\right)-z^{a}e^{-z}\sum_{k=0}^{n-1}\frac{z^{k}}{ \Gamma\left(a+k+1\right)}, Q\left(a+n,z\right)=Q\left(a,z\right)+z^{a}e^{-z}\sum_{k=0}^{n-1}\frac{z^{k}}{ \Gamma\left(a+k+1\right)}.

\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}z}\gamma\left(a,z\right)=-\frac{\mathrm{d}}{ \mathrm{d}z}\Gamma\left(a,z\right)=z^{a-1}e^{-z}, \left.\frac{\partial}{\partial a}\gamma^{*}\left(a,z\right)\right|_{a=0}=-E_{1 }\left(z\right)-\ln z.
For E_{1}\left(z\right) see §LABEL:sec:IG.GEI.DEF.

For n=0,1,2,\dots , \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{n}}{{\mathrm{d}z}^{n}}(z^{-a}\gamma\left(a,z\right))=(-1)^ {n}z^{-a-n}\gamma\left(a+n,z\right), \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{n}}{{\mathrm{d}z}^{n}}(z^{-a}\Gamma\left(a,z\right))=(-1)^ {n}z^{-a-n}\Gamma\left(a+n,z\right), \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{n}}{{\mathrm{d}z}^{n}}(e^{z}\gamma\left(a,z\right))=(-1)^{ n}{\left(1-a\right)_{n}}e^{z}\gamma\left(a-n,z\right), \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{n}}{{\mathrm{d}z}^{n}}(z^{a}e^{z}\gamma^{*}\left(a,z\right ))=z^{a-n}e^{z}\gamma^{*}\left(a-n,z\right), \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{n}}{{\mathrm{d}z}^{n}}(e^{z}\Gamma\left(a,z\right))=(-1)^{ n}{\left(1-a\right)_{n}}e^{z}\Gamma\left(a-n,z\right).

\Gamma\left(a+1\right)e^{z}\gamma^{*}\left(a,z\right)=\cfrac{1}{1-\cfrac{z}{a+ 1+\cfrac{z}{a+2-\cfrac{(a+1)z}{a+3+\cfrac{2z}{a+4-\cfrac{(a+2)z}{a+5+\cfrac{3z }{a+6-\cdots}}}}}}}, subject to a\neq-1,-2,\dots, , z^{-a}e^{z}\Gamma\left(a,z\right)=\cfrac{z^{-1}}{1+\cfrac{(1-a)z^{-1}}{1+ \cfrac{z^{-1}}{1+\cfrac{(2-a)z^{-1}}{1+\cfrac{2z^{-1}}{1+\cfrac{(3-a)z^{-1}}{1 +\cfrac{3z^{-1}}{1+\cdots}}}}}}}, subject to |\operatorname{ph}z|<\pi.
For these expansions and further information see ( ) .
See also ( , pp. 240–251) .
x^{1-a}e^{x}\Gamma\left(a,x\right)\leq 1, subject to x>0, 0<a\leq 1, \gamma\left(a,x\right)\geq\frac{x^{a-1}}{a}(1-e^{-x}), subject to x>0, 0<a\leq 1.
The inequalities in (LABEL:eq:IG.IQ.1) and (LABEL:eq:IG.IQ.2) are reversed when a\geq 1.
If \vartheta is defined by x^{1-a}e^{x}\Gamma\left(a,x\right)=1+\frac{a-1}{x}\vartheta, then \vartheta\to 1 as x\to\infty , and 0<\vartheta\leq 1, subject to x>0, a\leq 2.
For further inequalities of these types see ( ) and ( ) .
For hypergeometric polynomial representations of A_{n} and B_{n} , see ( , §14.6) .
Next, define I=\int_{0}^{x}t^{a-1}e^{t}\mathrm{d}t=\Gamma\left(a\right)x^{a}\gamma^{*}\left (a,-x\right), subject to \Re a>0.
Then \frac{(a+1)(a+2)-x}{(a+1)(a+2+x)}<ax^{-a}e^{-x}I<\frac{a+1}{a+1+x}, subject to x>0, a\geq 0.
Also, define c_{a}=(\Gamma\left(1+a\right))^{1/(a-1)}, d_{a}=(\Gamma\left(1+a\right))^{-1/a}.

Then \frac{x}{2a}\left(\left(1+\frac{2}{x}\right)^{a}-1\right)<x^{1-a}e^{x}\Gamma \left(a,x\right)\leq\frac{x}{ac_{a}}\left(\left(1+\frac{c_{a}}{x}\right)^{a}-1 \right), subject to x\geq 0, 0<a<1, and (1-e^{-\alpha_{a}x})^{a}\leq P\left(a,x\right)\leq(1-e^{-\beta_{a}x})^{a}, subject to x\geq 0, a>0, where \alpha_{a}=\begin{cases}1,&0<a<1,\\ d_{a},&a>1,\end{cases}, \beta_{a}=\begin{cases}d_{a},&0<a<1,\\ 1,&a>1.\end{cases } Equalities in (LABEL:eq:IG.IQ.10) apply only when a=1.
Lastly, \frac{\Gamma\left(n,n\right)}{\Gamma\left(n\right)}<\frac{1}{2}<\frac{\Gamma \left(n,n-1\right)}{\Gamma\left(n\right)}, subject to n=1,2,3,\dots.
Define u_{k}=(-1)^{k}{\left(1-a\right)_{k}}=(a-1)(a-2)\cdots(a-k), \Gamma\left(a,z\right)=z^{a-1}e^{-z}\left(\sum_{k=0}^{n-1}\frac{u_{k}}{z^{k}}+ R_{n}(a,z)\right), subject to n=1,2,\dots.
Then as z\to\infty with a and n fixed R_{n}(a,z)=O\left(z^{-n}\right), subject to |\operatorname{ph}z|\leq\tfrac{3}{2}\pi-\delta, where \delta denotes an arbitrary small positive constant.
If a is real and z ( =x ) is positive, then R_{n}(a,x) is bounded in absolute value by the first neglected term u_{n}/x^{n} and has the same sign provided that n\geq a-1.
For bounds on R_{n}(a,z) when a is real and z is complex see ( , pp. 109–112) .
For an exponentially-improved asymptotic expansion (§LABEL:sec:AS.RTSP.EIE) see ( ) .
\gamma\left(a,z\right)=z^{a}e^{-z}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\frac{z^{k}}{{\left(a \right)_{k+1}}}, subject to a\neq 0,-1,-2,\dots.

This expansion is absolutely convergent for all finite z , and it can also be regarded as a generalized asymptotic expansion (§LABEL:sec:AS.DEP.GAE) of \gamma\left(a,z\right) as a\to\infty in |\operatorname{ph}a|\leq\pi-\delta.
Also, P\left(a,z\right)\sim\frac{z^{a}e^{-z}}{\Gamma\left(1+a\right)}\sim(2\pi a)^{- \frac{1}{2}}e^{a-z}(z/a)^{a}, subject to a\to\infty, |\operatorname{ph}a|\leq\pi-\delta.

If z=\lambda a , with \lambda fixed, then as a\to\infty \gamma\left(a,z\right)\sim-z^{a}e^{-z}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\frac{(-a)^{k}b_{k}( \lambda)}{(z-a)^{2k+1}}, subject to 0<\lambda<1, |\operatorname{ph}a|\leq\frac{\pi}{2}-\delta.
\Gamma\left(a,z\right)\sim z^{a}e^{-z}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\frac{(-a)^{k}b_{k}( \lambda)}{(z-a)^{2k+1}}, subject to \lambda>1, |\operatorname{ph}a|\leq\frac{3\pi}{2}-\delta.
where b_{0}(\lambda)=1, b_{1}(\lambda)=\lambda, b_{2}(\lambda)=\lambda(2\lambda+1), and for k=1,2,\dots , b_{k}(\lambda)=\lambda(1-\lambda)b_{k-1}^{\prime}(\lambda)+(2k-1)\lambda b_{k- 1}(\lambda).
Sharp error bounds and an exponentially-improved extension for (LABEL:eq:IG.AE.7) can be found in ( ) .
This reference also contains explicit formulas for b_{k}(\lambda) in terms of Stirling numbers and for the case \lambda>1 an asymptotic expansion for b_{k}(\lambda) as k\to\infty.

The expansion (LABEL:eq:IG.AE.7) also applies when a is replaced by -a , \lambda<0 and |{\rm ph}\,a|\leq\frac{3\pi}{2}-\omega-\delta with \omega={\rm ph}(-\lambda+\ln\left(-\lambda\right)+\pi i) , 0<\omega<\pi.
For error bounds and an exponentially-improved extension for this later expansion, see ( ) .
If x=a+(2a)^{\frac{1}{2}}y and a\to+\infty , then P\left(a+1,x\right)=\tfrac{1}{2}\operatorname{erfc}\left(-y\right)-\frac{1}{3} \sqrt{\frac{2}{\pi a}}(1+y^{2})e^{-y^{2}}+O\left(a^{-1}\right),
in both cases uniformly with respect to bounded real values of y.
For Dawson’s integral F\left(y\right) see §LABEL:sec:ER.DF.DA.
See ( ) for these approximations, together with higher terms and extensions to complex variables.
For related expansions involving Hermite polynomials see ( ) .

As z\to\infty , \Gamma\left(z,z\right)\sim z^{z-1}e^{-z}\left(\sqrt{\frac{\pi}{2}}z^{\frac{1}{ 2}}-\frac{1}{3}+\frac{\sqrt{2\pi}}{24z^{\frac{1}{2}}}-\frac{4}{135z}+\frac{ \sqrt{2\pi}}{576z^{\frac{3}{2}}}+\frac{8}{2835z^{2}}+\dots\right), subject to |\operatorname{ph}z|\leq 2\pi-\delta.
For sharp error bounds and an exponentially-improved extension, see ( ) .
This reference also contains explicit formulas for the coefficients in terms of Stirling numbers.
For the function e_{n}(z) defined by (LABEL:eq:IG.SV.10),

\lim_{n\to\infty}\frac{e_{n}(nx)}{e^{nx}}=\begin{cases}0,&x>1,\\ \tfrac{1}{2},&x=1,\\ 1,&0\leq x<1.\end{cases } With x=1 , an asymptotic expansion of e_{n}(nx)/e^{nx} follows from (LABEL:eq:IG.AE.26) and (LABEL:eq:IG.AE.35).
If S_{n}(x) is defined by e^{nx}=e_{n}(nx)+\frac{(nx)^{n}}{n!}S_{n}(x) , then S_{n}(x)=\frac{\gamma\left(n+1,nx\right)}{(nx)^{n}e^{-nx}}.

Also, S_{n}(x)\sim\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}d_{k}(x)n^{-k}, subject to n\to\infty, uniformly for x\in(-\infty,1-\delta] , with d_{k}(x)=\frac{(-1)^{k}b_{k}(x)}{(1-x)^{2k+1}}, subject to k=0,1,2,\dots, and b_{k}(x) as in §LABEL:sec:IG.AE.LAZ.
For (LABEL:eq:IG.AE.29) and extensions to complex values of x see ( ) .
For a uniformly valid expansion for n\to\infty and x\in[\delta,1] , see ( ) .

section.title: Uniform Asymptotic Expansions for Large Parameter

para.sentence: Define \lambda=z/a, \eta=\left(2(\lambda-1-\ln\lambda)\right)^{1/2}, where the branch of the square root is continuous and satisfies \eta(\lambda)\sim\lambda-1 as \lambda\to 1.
Then \tfrac{1}{2}\eta^{2}=\lambda-1-\ln\lambda, \frac{\mathrm{d}\eta}{\mathrm{d}\lambda}=\frac{\lambda-1}{\lambda\eta}.

Also, denote P\left(a,z\right)=\tfrac{1}{2}\operatorname{erfc}\left(-\eta\sqrt{a/2}\right)- S(a,\eta), Q\left(a,z\right)=\tfrac{1}{2}\operatorname{erfc}\left(\eta\sqrt{a/2}\right)+S (a,\eta), \frac{e^{\pm\pi ia}}{2i\sin\left(\pi a\right)}Q\left(-a,ze^{\pm\pi i}\right)= \pm\tfrac{1}{2}\operatorname{erfc}\left(\pm i\eta\sqrt{a/2}\right)-iT(a,\eta), and z^{-a}\gamma^{*}\left(-a,-z\right)=\cos\left(\pi a\right)-2\sin\left(\pi a \right)\left(\frac{e^{\frac{1}{2}a\eta^{2}}}{\sqrt{\pi}}F\left(\eta\sqrt{a/2} \right)+T(a,\eta)\right), where F\left(x\right) is Dawson’s integral; see §LABEL:sec:ER.DF.DA.

Then as a\to\infty in the sector |\operatorname{ph}a|\leq\pi-\delta(<\pi) , S(a,\eta)\sim\frac{e^{-\frac{1}{2}a\eta^{2}}}{\sqrt{2\pi a}}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty }c_{k}(\eta)a^{-k}, T(a,\eta)\sim\frac{e^{\frac{1}{2}a\eta^{2}}}{\sqrt{2\pi a}}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} c_{k}(\eta)(-a)^{-k}, in each case uniformly with respect to \lambda in the sector |\operatorname{ph}\lambda|\leq 2\pi-\delta ( <2\pi ).

With \mu=\lambda-1 , the coefficients c_{k}(\eta) are given by c_{0}(\eta)=\frac{1}{\mu}-\frac{1}{\eta}, c_{1}(\eta)=\frac{1}{\eta^{3}}-\frac{1}{\mu^{3}}-\frac{1}{\mu^{2}}-\frac{1}{12 \mu}, c_{k}(\eta)=\frac{1}{\eta}\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}\eta}c_{k-1}(\eta)+(-1)^ {k}\frac{g_{k}}{\mu}, subject to k=1,2,\dots, where g_{k} , k=0,1,2,\dots , are the coefficients that appear in the asymptotic expansion ( LABEL:eq:GA.AE.PE.3) of \Gamma\left(z\right).

The right-hand sides of equations (LABEL:eq:IG.AE.43), (LABEL:eq:IG.AE.43a) have removable singularities at \eta=0 , and the Maclaurin series expansion of c_{k}(\eta) is given by c_{k}(\eta)=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}d_{k,n}\eta^{n}, subject to |\eta|<2\sqrt{\pi}, where d_{0,0}=-\tfrac{1}{3} , d_{0,n}=(n+2)\alpha_{n+2}, d_{k,n}=(-1)^{k}g_{k}d_{0,n}+(n+2)d_{k-1,n+2}, and \alpha_{3},\alpha_{4},\dots are defined by \lambda-1=\eta+\tfrac{1}{3}\eta^{2}+\sum_{n=3}^{\infty}\alpha_{n}\eta^{n}, subject to |\eta|<2\sqrt{\pi}.
For numerical values of d_{k,n} to 30D for k=0(1)9 and n=0(1)N_{k} , where N_{k}=28-4\left\lfloor k/2\right\rfloor , see ( ) .

Special cases are given by Q\left(a,a\right)\sim\frac{1}{2}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi a}}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}c_{ k}(0)a^{-k}, subject to |\operatorname{ph}a|\leq\pi-\delta, \frac{e^{\pm\pi ia}}{2i\sin\left(\pi a\right)}Q\left(-a,ae^{\pm\pi i}\right) \sim\pm\frac{1}{2}-\frac{i}{\sqrt{2\pi a}}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}c_{k}(0)(-a)^{-k}, subject to |\operatorname{ph}a|\leq\pi-\delta, where c_{0}(0)=-\tfrac{1}{3}, c_{1}(0)=-\tfrac{1}{540}, c_{2}(0)=\tfrac{25}{6048}, c_{3}(0)=\tfrac{101}{1\;55520}, c_{4}(0)=-\tfrac{31\;84811}{36951\;55200}, c_{5}(0)=-\tfrac{27\;45493}{81517\;36320}.
For error bounds for (LABEL:eq:IG.AE.39) see ( ) .
For the asymptotic behavior of c_{k}(\eta) as k\to\infty see ( ) and ( ) .
The last reference also includes an exponentially-improved version (§LABEL:sec:AS.RTSP.EIE) of the expansions (LABEL:eq:IG.AE.38b) and (LABEL:eq:IG.AE.39) for Q\left(a,z\right).

A different type of uniform expansion with coefficients that do not possess a removable singularity at z=a is given by \rselection{Q\left(a,z\right)\\ P\left(a,z\right)}\sim\frac{z^{a-\frac{1}{2}}e^{-z}}{\Gamma\left(a\right)}{ \left(d(\pm\chi)\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\frac{A_{k}(\chi)}{z^{k/2}}\mp\sum_{k=1}^{ \infty}\frac{B_{k}(\chi)}{z^{k/2}}\right)}, for z\to\infty in \left|\operatorname{ph}z\right|<\frac{1}{2}\pi , with \Re(z-a)\leq 0 for P\left(a,z\right) and \Re(z-a)\geq 0 for Q\left(a,z\right).

Here \chi=(z-a)/\sqrt{z}, d(\pm\chi)=\sqrt{\tfrac{1}{2}\pi}e^{\chi^{2}/2}\operatorname{erfc}\left(\pm \chi/\sqrt{2}\right), and A_{0}(\chi)=1, A_{1}(\chi)=\tfrac{1}{2}\chi+\tfrac{1}{6}\chi^{3}, B_{1}(\chi)=\tfrac{1}{3}+\tfrac{1}{6}\chi^{2}.
Higher coefficients A_{k}(\chi) , B_{k}(\chi) , up to k=8 , are given in ( ) .
Lastly, a uniform approximation for \Gamma\left(a,ax\right) for large a , with error bounds, can be found in ( ) .
For other uniform asymptotic approximations of the incomplete gamma functionsin terms of the function \operatorname{erfc} see ( ) and ( ) .
For asymptotic expansions, as a\to\infty , of the inverse function x=x(a,q) that satisfies the equation Q\left(a,x\right)=q see ( ) .
These expansions involve the inverse error function \operatorname{inverfc}\left(x\right) (§LABEL:sec:ER.IF), and are uniform with respect to q\in[0,1].
As a special case, x(a,\tfrac{1}{2})\sim a-\tfrac{1}{3}+\tfrac{8}{405}a^{-1}+\tfrac{184}{25515}a^ {-2}+\tfrac{2248}{34\;44525}a^{-3}+\cdots, subject to a\to\infty.
The function \gamma^{*}\left(a,x\right) has no real zeros for a\geq 0.
For a<0 and n=1,2,3,\dots , there exist: one negative zero x_{-}(a) and no positive zeros when 1-2n<a<2-2n ; one negative zero x_{-}(a) and one positive zero x_{+}(a) when -2n<a<1-2n.
The negative zero x_{-}(a) decreases monotonically in the interval -1<a<0 , and satisfies 1+a^{-1}<x_{-}(a)<\ln|a|, subject to -1<a<0.
When -5\leq a\leq 4 the behavior of the x -zeros as functions of a can be seen by taking the slice \gamma^{*}\left(a,x\right)=0 of the surface depicted in Figure LABEL:fig:IG.GV.RV.7.
Note that from (LABEL:eq:IG.SV.11)
\gamma^{*}\left(-n,0\right)=0 , n=1,2,3,\dots.
For asymptotic approximations for x_{+}(a) and x_{-}(a) as a\to-\infty see ( ) , with corrections by ( ) .
For more accurate asymptotic approximations see ( ) .

For information on the distribution and computation of zeros of \gamma\left(a,\lambda a\right) and \Gamma\left(a,\lambda a\right) in the complex \lambda -plane for large values of the positive real parameter a see ( ) .

For fixed x and n=1,2,3,\dots , \gamma^{*}\left(a,x\right) has: two zeros in each of the intervals -2n<a<2-2n when x<0 ; two zeros in each of the intervals -2n<a<1-2n when 0<x\leq x_{n}^{*} ; zeros at a=-n when x=0.
As x increases the positive zeros coalesce to form a double zero at ( a_{n}^{*},x_{n}^{*} ).
The values of the first six double zeros are given to 5D in Table LABEL:tab:IG.ZE.1.
For values up to n=10 see ( ) .
Approximations to a_{n}^{*} , x_{n}^{*} for large n can be found in ( ) .
When x>x_{n}^{*} a pair of conjugate trajectories emanate from the point a=a_{n}^{*} in the complex a -plane.
See ( ) for further information.

\int_{0}^{\infty}e^{-ax}\frac{\gamma\left(b,x\right)}{\Gamma\left(b\right)} \mathrm{d}x=\frac{(1+a)^{-b}}{a}, subject to \Re a>0, \Re b>-1, \int_{0}^{\infty}e^{-ax}\Gamma\left(b,x\right)\mathrm{d}x=\Gamma\left(b\right) \frac{1-(1+a)^{-b}}{a}, subject to \Re a>-1, \Re b>-1.
In (LABEL:eq:IG.DI.1) and (LABEL:eq:IG.DI.2) limiting values are used when b=0.

\int_{0}^{\infty}x^{a-1}\gamma\left(b,x\right)\mathrm{d}x=-\frac{\Gamma\left(a +b\right)}{a}, subject to \Re a<0, \Re(a+b)>0, \int_{0}^{\infty}x^{a-1}\Gamma\left(b,x\right)\mathrm{d}x=\frac{\Gamma\left(a+ b\right)}{a}, subject to \Re a>0, \Re(a+b)>0, \int_{0}^{\infty}x^{a-1}e^{-sx}\gamma\left(b,x\right)\mathrm{d}x=\frac{\Gamma \left(a+b\right)}{b(1+s)^{a+b}}\*F\left(1,a+b;1+b;1/(1+s)\right), subject to \Re s>0, \Re(a+b)>0, \int_{0}^{\infty}x^{a-1}e^{-sx}\Gamma\left(b,x\right)\mathrm{d}x=\frac{\Gamma \left(a+b\right)}{a(1+s)^{a+b}}\*F\left(1,a+b;1+a;s/(1+s)\right), subject to \Re s>-1, \Re(a+b)>0, \Re a>0.
For the hypergeometric function F\left(a,b;c;z\right) see §LABEL:sec:HY.GA.GS.
\gamma\left(a,\lambda x\right)=\lambda^{a}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\gamma\left(a+k,x \right)\frac{(1-\lambda)^{k}}{k!}.
For sums of infinite series whose terms include incomplete gamma functions, see ( , §5.2) .
For a generalization of the incomplete gamma function, including asymptotic approximations, see ( ) and ( ) .
Other generalizations are considered in ( ) and ( ) .
Throughout §§LABEL:sec:IG.IBF and LABEL:sec:IG.AEB we assume that a>0 , b>0 , and 0\leq x\leq 1.
However, in the case of §LABEL:sec:IG.IBF it is straightforward to continue most results analytically to other real values of a , b , and x , and also to complex values.

\mathrm{B}_{x}\left(a,b\right)=\int_{0}^{x}t^{a-1}(1-t)^{b-1}\mathrm{d}t, I_{x}\left(a,b\right)=\mathrm{B}_{x}\left(a,b\right)/\mathrm{B}\left(a,b\right), where, as in §LABEL:sec:GA.BF, \mathrm{B}\left(a,b\right) denotes the Beta function: \mathrm{B}\left(a,b\right)=\frac{\Gamma\left(a\right)\Gamma\left(b\right)}{ \Gamma\left(a+b\right)}.
I_{x}\left(a,b\right)=1-I_{1-x}\left(b,a\right).
I_{x}\left(m,n-m+1\right)=\sum_{j=m}^{n}\genfrac{(}{)}{0.0pt}{}{n}{j}x^{j}(1-x )^{n-j}, subject to m,n positive integers; 0\leq x<1.
Addendum: For a companion equation see (LABEL:eq:IG.DEB.5a).
I_{x}\left(a,a\right)=\tfrac{1}{2}I_{4x(1-x)}\left(a,\tfrac{1}{2}\right), subject to 0\leq x\leq\frac{1}{2}.
For a historical profile of \mathrm{B}_{x}\left(a,b\right) see ( ) .

\mathrm{B}_{x}\left(a,b\right)=\frac{x^{a}}{a}F\left(a,1-b;a+1;x\right), , \mathrm{B}_{x}\left(a,b\right)=\frac{x^{a}(1-x)^{b}}{a}F\left(a+b,1;a+1;x \right), , \mathrm{B}_{x}\left(a,b\right)=\frac{x^{a}(1-x)^{b-1}}{a}F\left({1,1-b\atop a+ 1};\frac{x}{x-1}\right).
For the hypergeometric function F\left(a,b;c;z\right) see §LABEL:sec:HY.GA.GS.

With a>0 , b>0 , and 0<x<1 , I_{x}\left(a,b\right)=\frac{x^{a}(1-x)^{b}}{2\pi i}\int_{c-i\infty}^{c+i\infty }s^{-a}(1-s)^{-b}\frac{\mathrm{d}s}{s-x}, where x<c<1 and the branches of s^{-a} and (1-s)^{-b} are continuous on the path and assume their principal values when s=c.
Further integral representations can be obtained by combining the results given in §LABEL:sec:IG.REB.RHF with §LABEL:sec:HY.IR.

With x^{\prime}=1-x, c=a+b-1, I_{x}\left(a,b\right)=xI_{x}\left(a-1,b\right)+x^{\prime}I_{x}\left(a,b-1 \right), , (a+b)I_{x}\left(a,b\right)=aI_{x}\left(a+1,b\right)+bI_{x}\left(a,b+1\right), (a+bx)I_{x}\left(a,b\right)=xbI_{x}\left(a-1,b+1\right)+aI_{x}\left(a+1,b \right), (b+ax^{\prime})I_{x}\left(a,b\right)=ax^{\prime}I_{x}\left(a+1,b-1\right)+bI_{ x}\left(a,b+1\right), aI_{x}\left(a+1,b\right)=(a+cx)I_{x}\left(a,b\right)-cxI_{x}\left(a-1,b\right), , bI_{x}\left(a,b+1\right)=(b+cx^{\prime})I_{x}\left(a,b\right)-cx^{\prime}I_{x} \left(a,b-1\right), I_{x}\left(a,b\right)=I_{x}\left(a+1,b-1\right)+\frac{x^{a}(x^{\prime})^{b-1}} {a\mathrm{B}\left(a,b\right)}, I_{x}\left(a,b\right)=I_{x}\left(a-1,b+1\right)-\frac{x^{a-1}(x^{\prime})^{b}} {b\mathrm{B}\left(a,b\right)}, I_{x}\left(a,b\right)=I_{x}\left(a+1,b\right)+\frac{x^{a}(x^{\prime})^{b}}{a \mathrm{B}\left(a,b\right)}, , I_{x}\left(a,b\right)=I_{x}\left(a,b+1\right)-\frac{x^{a}(x^{\prime})^{b}}{b \mathrm{B}\left(a,b\right)}.

I_{x}\left(a,b\right)=\frac{x^{a}(1-x)^{b}}{a\mathrm{B}\left(a,b\right)}\left( \cfrac{1}{1+\cfrac{d_{1}}{1+\cfrac{d_{2}}{1+\cfrac{d_{3}}{1+}}}}\cdots\right), where d_{2m}=\frac{m(b-m)x}{(a+2m-1)(a+2m)}, d_{2m+1}=-\frac{(a+m)(a+b+m)x}{(a+2m)(a+2m+1)}.
The 4m and 4m+1 convergents are less than I_{x}\left(a,b\right) , and the 4m+2 and 4m+3 convergents are greater than I_{x}\left(a,b\right).
See also ( , pp. 385–389) .
The expansion (LABEL:eq:IG.REB.7)converges rapidly for x<(a+1)/(a+b+2).
For x>(a+1)/(a+b+2) or 1-x<(b+1)/(a+b+2) , more rapid convergence is obtained by computing I_{1-x}\left(b,a\right) and using (LABEL:eq:IG.DEB.4).
For sums of infinite series whose terms involve the incomplete Beta function see ( , §62) .
I_{x}\left(m,n\right)=(1-x)^{n}\sum_{j=m}^{\infty}\genfrac{(}{)}{0.0pt}{}{n+j- 1}{j}x^{j}, subject to m,n positive integers; 0\leq x<1.
Compare (LABEL:eq:IG.DEB.5).

If b and x are fixed, with b>0 and 0<x<1 , then as a\to\infty I_{x}\left(a,b\right)={\Gamma\left(a+b\right)x^{a}(1-x)^{b-1}}\*\left(\sum_{k= 0}^{n-1}\frac{1}{\Gamma\left(a+k+1\right)\Gamma\left(b-k\right)}\left(\frac{x} {1-x}\right)^{k}+O\left(\frac{1}{\Gamma\left(a+n+1\right)}\right)\right), for each n=0,1,2,\dots.
If b=1,2,3,\dots and n\geq b , then the O -term can be omitted and the result is exact.
If b\to\infty and a and x are fixed, with a>0 and 0<x<1 , then (LABEL:eq:IG.AEB.LPFX1), with a and b interchanged and x replaced by 1-x , can be combined with (LABEL:eq:IG.DEB.4).
Let \xi=-\ln x.

Then as a\to\infty , with b ( >0 ) fixed, I_{x}\left(a,b\right)=\frac{\Gamma\left(a+b\right)}{\Gamma\left(a\right)}\left (\sum_{k=0}^{n-1}d_{k}F_{k}+O\left(a^{-n}\right)F_{0}\right), uniformly for x\in(0,1].

The functions F_{k} are defined by aF_{k+1}=(k+b-a\xi)F_{k}+k\xi F_{k-1}, with F_{0}=a^{-b}Q\left(b,a\xi\right), F_{1}=\frac{b-a\xi}{a}F_{0}+\frac{\xi^{b}e^{-a\xi}}{a\Gamma\left(b\right)}, and Q\left(a,z\right) as in §LABEL:sec:IG.PV.
The coefficients d_{k} are defined by the generating function \left(\frac{1-e^{-t}}{t}\right)^{b-1}=\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}d_{k}(t-\xi)^{k}.
In particular, d_{0}=\left(\frac{1-x}{\xi}\right)^{b-1}, d_{1}=\frac{x\xi+x-1}{(1-x)\xi}(b-1)d_{0}.
Compare also §LABEL:sec:BP.HOA.
A recurrence relation for the d_{k} can be found in ( ) .
Let x_{0}=a/(a+b).

Then as a+b\to\infty , I_{x}\left(a,b\right)\sim\tfrac{1}{2}\operatorname{erfc}\left(-\eta\sqrt{b/2} \right)+\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi(a+b)}}\*\left(\frac{x}{x_{0}}\right)^{a}\left( \frac{1-x}{1-x_{0}}\right)^{b}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\frac{(-1)^{k}c_{k}(\eta)}{(a +b)^{k}}, uniformly for x\in(0,1) and a/(a+b) , b/(a+b)\in[\delta,1-\delta] , where \delta again denotes an arbitrary small positive constant.
For \operatorname{erfc} see §LABEL:sec:ER.DF.ER.

Also, -\tfrac{1}{2}\eta^{2}=x_{0}\ln\left(\frac{x}{x_{0}}\right)+(1-x_{0})\ln\left( \frac{1-x}{1-x_{0}}\right), with \eta/(x-x_{0})>0 , and c_{0}(\eta)=\frac{1}{\eta}-\frac{\sqrt{x_{0}(1-x_{0})}}{x-x_{0}}, with limiting value c_{0}(0)=\frac{1-2x_{0}}{3\sqrt{x_{0}(1-x_{0})}}.
For this result, and for higher coefficients c_{k}(\eta) see ( , §11.3.3.2) .
All of the c_{k}(\eta) are analytic at \eta=0.
Let \widetilde{\Gamma}(z) denote the scaled gamma function \widetilde{\Gamma}(z)=(2\pi)^{-1/2}e^{z}z^{(1/2)-z}\Gamma\left(z\right), \mu=b/a , and x_{0} again be as in (LABEL:eq:IG.AEB.LPUAE2).

Then as a\to\infty I_{x}\left(a,b\right)\sim Q\left(b,a\zeta\right)-\frac{(2\pi b)^{-1/2}}{ \widetilde{\Gamma}(b)}\left(\frac{x}{x_{0}}\right)^{a}\left(\frac{1-x}{1-x_{0} }\right)^{b}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\frac{h_{k}(\zeta,\mu)}{a^{k}}, uniformly for b\in(0,\infty) and x\in(0,1).

Here \mu\ln\zeta-\zeta=\ln x+\mu\ln\left(1-x\right)+(1+\mu)\ln\left(1+\mu\right)-\mu, with (\zeta-\mu)/(x_{0}-x)>0 , and h_{0}(\zeta,\mu)=\mu\left(\frac{1}{\zeta-\mu}-\frac{(1+\mu)^{-3/2}}{x_{0}-x} \right), with limiting value h_{0}(\mu,\mu)=\frac{1}{3}\left(\frac{1-\mu}{\sqrt{1+\mu}}-1\right).
For this result and higher coefficients h_{k}(\zeta,\mu) see ( , §11.3.3.3) .
All of the h_{k}(\zeta,\mu) are analytic at \zeta=\mu (corresponding to x=x_{0} ).
For asymptotic expansions for large values of a and/or b of the x -solution of the equation I_{x}\left(a,b\right)=p, subject to 0\leq p\leq 1, see ( ) .
For p,z\in\mathbb{C} E_{p}\left(z\right)=z^{p-1}\Gamma\left(1-p,z\right).
Most properties of E_{p}\left(z\right) follow straightforwardly from those of \Gamma\left(a,z\right).
For an extensive treatment of E_{1}\left(z\right) see Chapter LABEL:ch:EX.
E_{p}\left(z\right)=z^{p-1}\int_{z}^{\infty}\frac{e^{-t}}{t^{p}}\mathrm{d}t.

When the path of integration excludes the origin and does not cross thenegative real axis (LABEL:eq:IG.EID.1)defines the principal value of E_{p}\left(z\right) , and unless indicated otherwise in the DLMF principal values are assumed.

E_{p}\left(z\right)=\int_{1}^{\infty}\frac{e^{-zt}}{t^{p}}\mathrm{d}t, subject to |\operatorname{ph}z|<\tfrac{1}{2}\pi, , E_{p}\left(z\right)=\frac{z^{p-1}e^{-z}}{\Gamma\left(p\right)}\int_{0}^{\infty }\frac{t^{p-1}e^{-zt}}{1+t}\mathrm{d}t, subject to |\operatorname{ph}z|<\tfrac{1}{2}\pi, \Re p>0.
Integral representations of Mellin–Barnes type for E_{p}\left(z\right) follow immediately from (LABEL:eq:IG.IR.13), (LABEL:eq:IG.IR.14), and (LABEL:eq:IG.EID.7).

subsection.title: Graphics

para.sentence: In Figures LABEL:fig:IG.GV.7–LABEL:fig:IG.GV.10, height corresponds to the absolute value of the function and color to the phase.
See LABEL:doc.help.vrml.aboutcolor.

subsection.sentence: Figure 8.19.2: E_{\frac{1}{2}}\left(x+iy\right) , -4\leq x\leq 4 , -4\leq y\leq 4 . Principal value. There is a branch cut along the negative real axis.
Figure 8.19.3: E_{1}\left(x+iy\right) , -4\leq x\leq 4 , -4\leq y\leq 4 . Principal value. There is a branch cut along the negative real axis.
Figure 8.19.4: E_{\frac{3}{2}}\left(x+iy\right) , -3\leq x\leq 3 , -3\leq y\leq 3 . Principal value. There is a branch cut along the negative real axis.
Figure 8.19.5: E_{2}\left(x+iy\right) , -3\leq x\leq 3 , -3\leq y\leq 3 . Principal value. There is a branch cut along the negative real axis.

para.sentence: E_{0}\left(z\right)=z^{-1}e^{-z}, subject to z\neq 0, E_{p}\left(0\right)=\frac{1}{p-1}, subject to \Re p>1, E_{n}\left(z\right)=\frac{(-z)^{n-1}}{(n-1)!}E_{1}\left(z\right)+\frac{e^{-z}} {(n-1)!}\sum_{k=0}^{n-2}(n-k-2)!(-z)^{k}, subject to n=2,3,\dots.

For n=1,2,3,\dots , E_{n}\left(z\right)=\frac{(-z)^{n-1}}{(n-1)!}(\psi\left(n\right)-\ln z)-\sum_{ \begin{subarray}{c}k=0\\ k\neq n-1\end{subarray}}^{\infty}\frac{(-z)^{k}}{k!(1-n+k)} , and E_{n}\left(z\right)=\frac{(-1)^{n}z^{n-1}}{(n-1)!}\ln z+\frac{e^{-z}}{(n-1)!} \sum_{k=1}^{n-1}(-z)^{k-1}\Gamma\left(n-k\right)+\frac{e^{-z}(-z)^{n-1}}{(n-1) !}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\frac{z^{k}}{k!}\psi\left(k+1\right) , with |\operatorname{ph}z|\leq\pi in both equations.
For \psi\left(x\right) see §LABEL:sec:GA.Def.GP.

When p\in\mathbb{C} E_{p}\left(z\right)=z^{p-1}\Gamma\left(1-p\right)-\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\frac{(-z )^{k}}{k!(1-p+k)} , E_{p}\left(z\right)=\Gamma\left(1-p\right)\left(z^{p-1}-e^{-z}\sum_{k=0}^{ \infty}\frac{z^{k}}{\Gamma\left(2-p+k\right)}\right), again with |\operatorname{ph}z|\leq\pi in both equations.
The right-hand sides are replaced by their limiting forms when p=1,2,3,\dots.
pE_{p+1}\left(z\right)+zE_{p}\left(z\right)=e^{-z}.
\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}z}E_{p}\left(z\right)=-E_{p-1}\left(z\right), , \frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}z}(e^{z}E_{p}\left(z\right))=e^{z}E_{p}\left(z \right)\left(1+\frac{p-1}{z}\right)-\frac{1}{z}.
For j=1,2,3,\dots , \frac{{\partial}^{j}E_{p}\left(z\right)}{{\partial p}^{j}}=(-1)^{j}\int_{1}^{ \infty}(\ln t)^{j}t^{-p}e^{-zt}\mathrm{d}t, subject to \Re z>0.
For properties and numerical tables see ( ) , and also(when p=1 ) ( ) .
E_{p}\left(z\right)=z^{p-1}e^{-z}U\left(p,p,z\right).
For U\left(a,b,z\right) see §LABEL:sec:CH.MU.DE.KU.
E_{p}\left(z\right)=e^{-z}\left(\cfrac{1}{z+\cfrac{p}{1+\cfrac{1}{z+\cfrac{p+1 }{1+\cfrac{2}{z+\cdots}}}}}\right), subject to |\operatorname{ph}z|<\pi.
See also ( , pp. 277–285) .
The general function E_{p}\left(z\right) is attained by extending the path in (LABEL:eq:IG.EID.1)across the negative real axis.
Unless p is a nonpositive integer, E_{p}\left(z\right) has a branch point at z=0.
For z\neq 0 eachbranch of E_{p}\left(z\right) is an entire function of p.

sentence.Math: E_{p}\left(ze^{2m\pi i}\right)=\frac{2\pi ie^{mp\pi i}}{\Gamma\left(p\right)} \frac{\sin\left(mp\pi\right)}{\sin\left(p\pi\right)}z^{p-1}+E_{p}\left(z\right), subject to m\in\mathbb{Z}, z\neq 0.

para.sentence: For n=1,2,3,\dots and x>0 , \frac{n-1}{n}E_{n}\left(x\right)<E_{n+1}\left(x\right)<E_{n}\left(x\right), \left(E_{n}\left(x\right)\right)^{2}<E_{n-1}\left(x\right)E_{n+1}\left(x\right), \frac{1}{x+n}<e^{x}E_{n}\left(x\right)\leq\frac{1}{x+n-1}, \frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}\frac{E_{n}\left(x\right)}{E_{n-1}\left(x\right) }>0.

\int_{z}^{\infty}E_{p-1}\left(t\right)\mathrm{d}t=E_{p}\left(z\right), subject to |\operatorname{ph}z|<\pi, \int_{0}^{\infty}e^{-at}E_{n}\left(t\right)\mathrm{d}t=\frac{(-1)^{n-1}}{a^{n} }\left(\ln\left(1+a\right)+\sum_{k=1}^{n-1}\frac{(-1)^{k}a^{k}}{k}\right), subject to n=1,2,\dots, \Re a>-1, \int_{0}^{\infty}e^{-at}t^{b-1}E_{p}\left(t\right)\mathrm{d}t=\frac{\Gamma \left(b\right)(1+a)^{-b}}{p+b-1}\*F\left(1,b;p+b;a/(1+a)\right), subject to \Re a>-1, \Re(p+b)>1.

\int_{0}^{\infty}E_{p}\left(t\right)E_{q}\left(t\right)\mathrm{d}t=\frac{L(p)+ L(q)}{p+q-1}, subject to p>0, q>0, p+q>1, where L(p)=\int_{0}^{\infty}e^{-t}E_{p}\left(t\right)\mathrm{d}t=\frac{1}{2p}F\left( 1,1;1+p;\tfrac{1}{2}\right), subject to p>0.
For the hypergeometric function F\left(a,b;c;z\right) see §LABEL:sec:HY.GA.GS. When p=1,2,3,\dots , L(p) can also be evaluated via (LABEL:eq:IG.INE.2).
For collections of integrals involving E_{p}\left(z\right) , especially for integer p , see ( , §§7.1–7.2) and ( ) .
For higher-order generalized exponential integrals see ( ) and ( ) .

E_{p}\left(z\right)=\frac{e^{-z}}{z}\left(\sum_{k=0}^{n-1}(-1)^{k}\frac{{\left (p\right)_{k}}}{z^{k}}+(-1)^{n}\frac{{\left(p\right)_{n}}e^{z}}{z^{n-1}}E_{n+p }\left(z\right)\right), subject to n=1,2,3,\dots.

As z\to\infty E_{p}\left(z\right)\sim\frac{e^{-z}}{z}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}(-1)^{k}\frac{{\left (p\right)_{k}}}{z^{k}}, subject to |\operatorname{ph}z|\leq\frac{3}{2}\pi-\delta, and E_{p}\left(z\right)\sim\pm\frac{2\pi i}{\Gamma\left(p\right)}e^{\mp p\pi i}z^{ p-1}+\frac{e^{-z}}{z}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\frac{(-1)^{k}{\left(p\right)_{k}}}{z^ {k}}, subject to \tfrac{1}{2}\pi+\delta\leq\pm\operatorname{ph}z\leq\tfrac{7}{2}\pi-\delta, \delta again denoting an arbitrary small positive constant.

Where the sectors of validity of (LABEL:eq:IG.AEE.1a) and (LABEL:eq:IG.AEE.4)overlap the contribution of the first term on the right-hand side of (LABEL:eq:IG.AEE.4) is exponentially small compared to the other contribution; compare §LABEL:sec:AS.RTSP.CF.
For an exponentially-improved asymptotic expansion of E_{p}\left(z\right) see §LABEL:sec:AS.RTSP.EIE.

For x\geq 0 and p>1 let x=\lambda p and define A_{0}(\lambda)=1 , A_{k+1}(\lambda)=(1-2k\lambda)A_{k}(\lambda)+\lambda(\lambda+1)\frac{\mathrm{d }A_{k}(\lambda)}{\mathrm{d}\lambda}, subject to k=0,1,2,\dots, so that A_{k}(\lambda) is a polynomial in \lambda of degree k-1 when k\geq 1.
In particular, A_{1}(\lambda)=1, A_{2}(\lambda)=1-2\lambda, A_{3}(\lambda)=1-8\lambda+6\lambda^{2}.
Then as p\to\infty E_{p}\left(\lambda p\right)\sim\frac{e^{-\lambda p}}{(\lambda+1)p}\sum_{k=0}^{ \infty}\frac{A_{k}(\lambda)}{(\lambda+1)^{2k}}\frac{1}{p^{k}}, uniformly for \lambda\in[0,\infty).
For further information, including extensions to complex values of x and p , see ( , §4) and ( ) .

With \gamma and \Gamma denoting here the general values of the incomplete gamma functions (§LABEL:sec:IG.PV), we define \mathrm{ci}\left(a,z\right)\pm i\mathrm{si}\left(a,z\right)=e^{\pm\frac{1}{2} \pi ia}\Gamma\left(a,ze^{\mp\frac{1}{2}\pi i}\right), , \mathrm{Ci}\left(a,z\right)\pm i\mathrm{Si}\left(a,z\right)=e^{\pm\frac{1}{2} \pi ia}\gamma\left(a,ze^{\mp\frac{1}{2}\pi i}\right).

From §§LABEL:sec:IG.PV and LABEL:sec:IG.IGF.AC it follows that each of the four functions \mathrm{si}\left(a,z\right) , \mathrm{ci}\left(a,z\right) , \mathrm{Si}\left(a,z\right) , and \mathrm{Ci}\left(a,z\right) is a multivalued function of z with branch point at z=0.

Furthermore, \mathrm{si}\left(a,z\right) and \mathrm{ci}\left(a,z\right) are entire functions of a , and \mathrm{Si}\left(a,z\right) and \mathrm{Ci}\left(a,z\right) are meromorphic functions of a with simple poles at a=-1,-3,-5,\dots and a=0,-2,-4,\dots , respectively.

When \operatorname{ph}z=0 (and when a\neq-1,-3,-5,\dots , in the case of \mathrm{Si}\left(a,z\right) , or a\neq 0,-2,-4,\dots , in the case of \mathrm{Ci}\left(a,z\right) ) the principal values of \mathrm{si}\left(a,z\right) , \mathrm{ci}\left(a,z\right) , \mathrm{Si}\left(a,z\right) , and \mathrm{Ci}\left(a,z\right) are defined by (LABEL:eq:IG.DGC.10) and (LABEL:eq:IG.DGC.3) with the incomplete gamma functions assuming theirprincipal values (§LABEL:sec:IG.PV).
Elsewhere in the sector |\operatorname{ph}z|\leq\pi the principal values are defined by analytic continuation from \operatorname{ph}z=0 ; compare §LABEL:sec:EF.FN.LOG.

From here on it is assumed that unless indicated otherwise the functions \mathrm{si}\left(a,z\right) , \mathrm{ci}\left(a,z\right) , \mathrm{Si}\left(a,z\right) , and \mathrm{Ci}\left(a,z\right) have their principal values.

Properties of the four functions that are stated below in §§LABEL:sec:IG.GCI.IR and LABEL:sec:IG.GCI.INTER follow directly from the definitions given above, together with properties of the incomplete gamma functions given earlier in this chapter.

In the case of §LABEL:sec:IG.GCI.INTER the equation \int_{0}^{\infty}t^{a-1}e^{\pm\mathrm{i}t}\mathrm{d}t=e^{\pm\frac{1}{2}\pi \mathrm{i}a}\Gamma\left(a\right), subject to 0<\Re a<1, (obtained from (LABEL:eq:GA.Def.GP.1) by rotation of the integration path) is also needed.

\mathrm{si}\left(a,z\right)=\int_{z}^{\infty}t^{a-1}\sin t\mathrm{d}t, subject to \Re a<1, , \mathrm{ci}\left(a,z\right)=\int_{z}^{\infty}t^{a-1}\cos t\mathrm{d}t, subject to \Re a<1, , \mathrm{Si}\left(a,z\right)=\int_{0}^{z}t^{a-1}\sin t\mathrm{d}t, subject to \Re a>-1, , \mathrm{Ci}\left(a,z\right)=\int_{0}^{z}t^{a-1}\cos t\mathrm{d}t, subject to \Re a>0.
In these representations the integration paths do not cross the negative real axis, and in the case of (LABEL:eq:IG.DGC.8) and (LABEL:eq:IG.DGC.6) the paths also exclude the origin.

\mathrm{Si}\left(a,z\right)=\Gamma\left(a\right)\sin\left(\tfrac{1}{2}\pi a \right)-\mathrm{si}\left(a,z\right), subject to a\neq-1,-3,-5,\dots, \mathrm{Ci}\left(a,z\right)=\Gamma\left(a\right)\cos\left(\tfrac{1}{2}\pi a \right)-\mathrm{ci}\left(a,z\right), subject to a\neq 0,-2,-4,\dots.
\mathrm{si}\left(0,z\right)=-\mathrm{si}\left(z\right), \mathrm{ci}\left(0,z\right)=-\mathrm{Ci}\left(z\right), \mathrm{Si}\left(0,z\right)=\mathrm{Si}\left(z\right).
For the functions on the right-hand sides of (LABEL:eq:IG.GCI.SV1) and (LABEL:eq:IG.PCS.8)see §LABEL:sec:EX.DF.SC.

\mathrm{Si}\left(a,\infty\right)=\Gamma\left(a\right)\sin\left(\tfrac{1}{2}\pi a \right), subject to a\neq-1,-3,-5,\dots, , \mathrm{Ci}\left(a,\infty\right)=\Gamma\left(a\right)\cos\left(\tfrac{1}{2}\pi a \right), subject to a\neq 0,-2,-4,\dots.

\mathrm{Si}\left(a,z\right)=z^{a}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\frac{(-1)^{k}z^{2k+1}}{(2 k+a+1)(2k+1)!}, subject to a\neq-1,-3,-5,\dots, \mathrm{Ci}\left(a,z\right)=z^{a}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\frac{(-1)^{k}z^{2k}}{(2k+ a)(2k)!}, subject to a\neq 0,-2,-4,\dots.

\mathrm{Si}\left(a,z\right)=z^{a}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\frac{\left(2k+\frac{3}{2} \right){\left(1-\frac{1}{2}a\right)_{k}}}{{\left(\frac{1}{2}+\frac{1}{2}a \right)_{k+1}}}\mathsf{j}_{2k+1}\left(z\right), subject to a\neq-1,-3,-5,\dots, , \mathrm{Ci}\left(a,z\right)=z^{a}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\frac{\left(2k+\frac{1}{2} \right){\left(\frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{2}a\right)_{k}}}{{\left(\frac{1}{2}a\right) _{k+1}}}\mathsf{j}_{2k}\left(z\right), subject to a\neq 0,-2,-4,\dots.
For \mathsf{j}_{n}\left(z\right) see §LABEL:sec:BS.DBP.SS. For (LABEL:eq:IG.GCI.BES1), (LABEL:eq:IG.GCI.BES2), and further expansions in series of Bessel functions see ( , pp. 56–57) .
f(a,z)=\mathrm{si}\left(a,z\right)\cos z-\mathrm{ci}\left(a,z\right)\sin z, , g(a,z)=\mathrm{si}\left(a,z\right)\sin z+\mathrm{ci}\left(a,z\right)\cos z.
, \mathrm{si}\left(a,z\right)=f(a,z)\cos z+g(a,z)\sin z, , \mathrm{ci}\left(a,z\right)=-f(a,z)\sin z+g(a,z)\cos z.
When |\operatorname{ph}z|<\pi and \Re a<1 , f(a,z)=\int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{\sin t}{(t+z)^{1-a}}\mathrm{d}t, g(a,z)=\int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{\cos t}{(t+z)^{1-a}}\mathrm{d}t.

When |\operatorname{ph}z|<\frac{1}{2}\pi , f(a,z)=\frac{z^{a}}{2}\int_{0}^{\infty}\left((1+it)^{a-1}+(1-it)^{a-1}\right)e ^{-zt}\mathrm{d}t, g(a,z)=\frac{z^{a}}{2i}\int_{0}^{\infty}\left((1-it)^{a-1}-(1+it)^{a-1}\right) e^{-zt}\mathrm{d}t.

When z\to\infty with |\operatorname{ph}z|\leq\pi-\delta ( <\pi ), f(a,z)\sim z^{a-1}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\frac{(-1)^{k}{\left(1-a\right)_{2k}}}{z^ {2k}}, , g(a,z)\sim z^{a-1}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\frac{(-1)^{k}{\left(1-a\right)_{2k+1}}}{ z^{2k+1}}.
For the corresponding expansions for \mathrm{si}\left(a,z\right) and \mathrm{ci}\left(a,z\right) apply (LABEL:eq:IG.AUX.4) and (LABEL:eq:IG.AUX.3).

The so-called terminant function F_{p}\left(z\right) , defined by F_{p}\left(z\right)=\frac{\Gamma\left(p\right)}{2\pi}z^{1-p}E_{p}\left(z\right )=\frac{\Gamma\left(p\right)}{2\pi}\Gamma\left(1-p,z\right), plays a fundamental role in re-expansions of remainder terms in asymptotic expansions, including exponentially-improved expansions and a smooth interpretation of the Stokes phenomenon.
See §§LABEL:sec:AS.RTSP.CF–LABEL:sec:AS.RTSP.EIE2 and the references supplied in these subsections.

subsection.title: Riemann Zeta Function and Incomplete Riemann Zeta Function

para.sentence: The function \Gamma\left(a,z\right) , with |\operatorname{ph}a|\leq\tfrac{1}{2}\pi and \operatorname{ph}z=\tfrac{1}{2}\pi , has an intimate connection with the Riemann zeta function \zeta\left(s\right) (§LABEL:sec:ZE.Def.Def) on the critical line \Re s=\tfrac{1}{2}.
See ( ) .

If \zeta_{x}(s) denotes the incomplete Riemann zeta function defined by \zeta_{x}(s)=\frac{1}{\Gamma\left(s\right)}\int_{0}^{x}\frac{t^{s-1}}{e^{t}-1} \mathrm{d}t, subject to \Re s>1, so that \lim_{x\to\infty}\zeta_{x}(s)=\zeta\left(s\right) , then \zeta_{x}(s)=\sum_{k=1}^{\infty}k^{-s}P\left(s,kx\right), subject to \Re s>1.
For further information on \zeta_{x}(s) , including zeros and uniform asymptotic approximations, see ( ) and ( ) .

The Debye functions \int_{0}^{x}t^{n}\left(e^{t}-1\right)^{-1}\mathrm{d}t and \int_{x}^{\infty}t^{n}\left(e^{t}-1\right)^{-1}\mathrm{d}t are closely related to the incomplete Riemann zeta function and the Riemann zeta function.
See ( , p. 998) and ( , Chapter 23) .
The functions P\left(a,x\right) and Q\left(a,x\right) are used extensively in statistics as the probability integrals of the gamma distribution; see ( , pp. 337–414) .
Particular forms are the chi-square distribution functions; see ( , pp. 415–493) .
The function \mathrm{B}_{x}\left(a,b\right) and its normalization I_{x}\left(a,b\right) play a similar role in statistics in connection with the beta distribution; see ( , pp. 210–275) .
In queueing theory the Erlang loss function is used, which can be expressed in terms of the reciprocal of Q\left(a,x\right) ; see ( ) and ( , pp. 80, 316–319) .

The function \gamma\left(a,x\right) appears in: discussions of power-law relaxation times in complex physical systems ( ( ) ); logarithmic oscillations in relaxation times for proteins ( ( ) ); Gaussian orbitals and exponential (Slater) orbitals in quantum chemistry ( ( ) , ( ) ); population biology and ecological systems ( ( ) ).
The function I_{x}\left(a,b\right) appears in: Monte Carlo sampling instatistical mechanics ( ( ) ); analysis of packings of soft or granular objects ( ( ) ); growth formulas in cosmology ( ( ) ).
The function E_{p}\left(x\right) , with p>0 , appears in theories of transport and radiative equilibrium ( ( ) , ( ) , ( ) ).

With more general values of p , E_{p}\left(x\right) supplies fundamental auxiliary functions that are used in the computation of molecular electronic integrals in quantum chemistry ( ( ) , ( ) ), and also wave acoustics of overlapping sound beams ( ( ) ).

Although the series expansions in §§LABEL:sec:IG.SE, LABEL:sec:IG.GEI.SEE, and LABEL:sec:IG.GCI.SE converge for all finite values of z , they are cumbersome to use when |z| is large owing to slowness of convergence and cancellation.
For large |z| the corresponding asymptotic expansions (generally divergent) are used instead.
See also ( , pp. 101–102) and ( ) .
See ( ) for the numerical computation of \Gamma\left(a,z\right) from (LABEL:eq:IG.IR.5) by means of the trapezoidal rule.

( ) describes an algorithm for computing P\left(a,x\right) and Q\left(a,x\right) for a\geq 0 , x\geq 0 , and a+x\neq 0 from the uniform expansions in §LABEL:sec:IG.UAE. The algorithm supplies 14S accuracy.
A numerical inversion procedure is also given for calculating the value of x (with 10S accuracy), when a and P\left(a,x\right) are specified, based on Newton’s rule (§LABEL:sec:NM.NLE.NEWTON).
See also ( ) .
The computation of \gamma\left(a,z\right) and \Gamma\left(a,z\right) by means of continued fractions is described in ( ) and ( , §§4.3, 5) .
See also ( ) and ( , p. 280) .
Expansions involving incomplete gamma functions often require the generation of sequences P\left(a+n,x\right) , Q\left(a+n,x\right) , or \gamma^{*}\left(a+n,x\right) for fixed a and n=0,1,2,\dots.
An efficient procedure, based partly on the recurrence relations (LABEL:eq:IG.RF.4) and (LABEL:eq:IG.RF.5), is described in ( ) .
Stable recursive schemes for the computation of E_{p}\left(x\right) are described in ( ) for x>0 and integer p.
For x>0 and real p see ( ) and ( ) .
See also ( ) and ( ) .
For tables published before 1961 see ( ) and ( ) .

( ) tabulates P\left(a,x\right) for a=0.05(.05)10(.1)20(.25)7 0, 0.0001\leq x\leq 250 to 10D. ( ) tabulates P\left(a,x\right) and Q\left(a,x\right) (with different notation) for a=0(.05) 3, x=0(.05) 1 to 7D. ( ) tabulates the function I(u,p) ( =P\left(p+1,u\right) ) for p=-1(.05)0(.1)5(.2)5 0, u=0(.1)u_{p } to 7D, where I(u,u_{p}) rounds off to 1 to 7D; also I(u,p) for p=-0.75(.01)- 1, u=0(.1) 6 to 5D. ( , Table 3.8) tabulates \gamma\left(a,x\right) for a=0.5,1,3,5,10,25,50,10 0, x=0(.1)1(1)3,5(5)30,50,10 0 to 8D or 8S.
( ) tabulates I_{x}\left(a,b\right) for x=0.01(.01) 1, a,b=0.5(.5)11(1)5 0, with b\leq a , to 7D. ( , Table 3.9) tabulates I_{x}\left(a,b\right) for x=0(.05) 1, a=0.5,1,3,5,1 0, b=1,10 to 8D.

5 to 6S. ( ) presents a short table of E_{p}\left(x\right) for p=-\tfrac{9}{2}(1)-\tfrac{1}{2} , 0\leq x\leq 200 to 14S. ( ) tabulates E_{n}\left(x\right) for n=0(1)20 , x=0(.01)2(.1)1 0 to 4-9S; e^{x}E_{n}\left(x\right) for n=2(1)10 , x=10(.1)2 0 to 7D; e^{x}E_{p}\left(x\right) for p=0(.1) 1, x=0.01(.01)7(.05)12(.1)2 0 to 7S or 7D.
( ) tabulates E_{n}\left(x\right) for n=1(1)10 , x=0.01(.01) 5 to 7D. ( , Table 19.1)tabulates

( ) gives a simple approximation for the function F(p,x)=x^{-p}e^{x^{2}/2}\int_{x}^{\infty}e^{-t^{2}/2}t^{p}\mathrm{d}t (which is related to the incomplete gamma function by a change of variables) for real p and large positive x.
This takes the form F(p,x)=4x/h(p,x) , approximately, where h(p,x)=3(x^{2}-p)+\sqrt{(x^{2}-p)^{2}+8(x^{2}+p)} and is shown to produce an absolute error O\left(x^{-7}\right) as x\to\infty.
( , §4.3) gives Padé approximation methods, combined with a detailed analysis of the error terms, valid for real and complex variables except on the negative real z -axis.
See also ( , §3) .

( , pp. 25, 40–41) gives Chebyshev-series expansions for \Gamma\left(a,\omega z\right) (by specifying parameters) with 1\leq\omega<\infty , and \gamma\left(a,\omega z\right) with 0\leq\omega\leq 1 ; see also ( , §3) .
( , p. 186) gives hypergeometric polynomial representations that converge uniformly on compact subsets of the z -plane that exclude z=0 and are valid for \left|\operatorname{ph}z\right|<\pi.
( , p. 103) gives Chebyshev-series expansions for E_{1}\left(x\right) and related functions for x\geq 5.

( , p. 106) gives rational and Padé approximations, with remainders, for E_{1}\left(z\right) and z^{-1}\int_{0}^{z}t^{-1}(1-e^{-t})\mathrm{d}t for complex z with \left|\operatorname{ph}z\right|\leq\pi.
( ) gives polynomial and rational approximations for E_{p}\left(x\right)=(e^{-x}/x)P(z) , approximately, where P(z) denotes a quotient of polynomials of equal degree in z=x^{-1}.
In this section we provide links to the research literature describing the implementation of algorithms in software for the evaluation of functions described in this chapter.
Citations in bulleted lists refer to papers for which research software has been made available and can be downloaded via the Web.
References to research software that is available in other ways is listed separately.
A more complete list of available software for computing these functions is found in the LABEL:software.
For another listing of Web-accessible software for the functions in this chapter, see .
